unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate critical analytical and integrative thinking in applying developmental theory and research in early childhood
Have a good understanding of child development theory to enable the critical assessment of children’s learning environments
Communicate child development research effectively to other professionals and parents
Use sound analytical skills and evidence from child development research to address everyday problems concerned with children’s early development
Utilise child development knowledge in actively contributing to policy discussions concerning early childhood practice

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading preparation for each weekly class and also before attending seminars/on-campus days.
iLearn engagement in discussion topics, following convenor announcement, use of additional resources and learning materials, downloading essential and reading documents.

enrolment_rules.description: [Admission to (MTeach(0-5) or GradCertEChild) and (ECED602 or ECHE6020)] or [admission to MEChild or MEd or MEdLead or MIndigenousEd or MSpecEd or GradCertEdS]

assessments.description: Short answer and multiple choice questions on content from lectures and readings for topics 1 - 4, including Introductory Lecture on unit.
750wd online information resource for parents on selected child development topic

relationships.academic_item_name: Early Childhood Development Research and Practice

data.subject_search_title: ECHE8240 - Early Childhood Development Research and Practice
data.description: This unit is designed to extend students' knowledge of child development with a particular emphasis on approaches to understanding and measuring child development, considerations for quality in childcare, and evaluation of children's environments. Recent research studies of child development, especially in relation to prior-to-school settings, will be used as a major resource for examining contemporary theory and research in child development. Students will analyse research to develop their skills in using evidence-based approaches in teaching, to inform policy, and to evaluate programs within prior-to-school settings.
